newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordanian shares slip as Arab Bank falls.
newsitem.headline: Jordanian shares slip as Arab Bank falls.

text.p: Jordan's official stock market index fell back slightly on Monday when a three-day surge in Arab Bank shares petered out in profit-taking, brokers said.

Arab Bank, which has dominated bourse trading and driven the index upwards in a generally weak market, gained 4.5 dinars to a fresh five-year high of 284.5 dinars ($401) before easing to close at 278 dinars, down two dinars.
It helped drag the official 60-share Amman Financial Market (AFM) index down 0.37 percent to 163.69 points after accounting for 40 percent of Monday's turnover.
"The story of the market is Arab Bank," said broker Ibrahim Odeh of Wataniyeh Financial Services.
Profit-takers moved in when the share price started slipping, Odeh said, and it could ease further.
But he said the medium-term outlook was for more gains, with some dealers forecasting Arab Bank shares would soon rise to around 300 dinars.

Brokers attribute Arab Bank's recent rise -- it climbed 16 dinars in three trading sessions -- to forecasts of strong 1997 profits, expectations of a bonus share offering, and government plans to scrap foreign share ownership ceilings.
Investment firm National Portfolio, which has a large Arab Bank shareholding, also fell on Monday despite foreign demand, Odeh said. It dropped 0.08 dinars to 1.45 dinars.
Overall falling shares outnumbered gainers on Monday by 17 to nine, with another 17 shares trading but closing unchanged.

The private Pearl Index of the 45 best-performing shares in terms of turnover and financial performance fell 0.48 percent to 80.49 points, 3.48 percent down from the start of the year. $1 = 0.709 dinars
